comment.body:
Hi @leftside: sorry I didn't see your comments. I didn't realize that even on my own blog I need to actively tick "Comments" in the Following box :)

You can see the blog's main URL at https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs/the_papers

Then you can scroll down to find whatever date you need, clicking "More Stories" at the bottom to find older ones. Here's the original link for the 28th of March:
https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-the-papers-47728858

You'll notice all the images of newspapers are gone already from the original clearnet site.

> [satoxyn1](#comment_1_1LGApmQZPN49nawg4HQQgf8ToVUPxGe2Zq): Vremya i steklo (time and glass) is a pun on vremya isteklo (время истекло, time's up).

I wondered what it meant. Thanks!

> [satoxyn1](#comment_2_1LGApmQZPN49nawg4HQQgf8ToVUPxGe2Zq): You can find several masters at rutracker. Here's 404 song: https://rutracker.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=5150048I used it for H.265 encoding tests. You can compress it to ~40 MB H.265 video without significant quality loss!

I don't know if I'll go to the trouble of reencoding this myself (that's another thing on my list of things to learn), but thanks for the tip.

For now, what would be great is a solution to ZeroBlog not accepting embedding of WebM :)

@arch17pd: Thanks!
One drawback I've noticed though, The Papers zite still doesn't have as many peers as this one, so sometimes when I make a post I get "Content publish failed" message.
@leftside: I understand that videos can be converted. What I don't understand is why those sites don't accept MKV in the first place. Is MKV "bad" for streaming or something?

Do you mean formats like mp4 and webm have only one codec, but mkv can contain any of many different codecs? (x264, x265 etc.)? And that's why sites focused on streaming/playing on the webpage disallow MKV?
